articles.headline: U.S. Proposal for 15% Global Minimum Tax Wins Support From 130 Countries
articles.snippet: A 15 percent minimum tax rate would generate $150 billion in additional tax revenue each year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
articles.abstract: A 15 percent minimum tax rate would generate $150 billion in additional tax revenue each year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — An effort to push the most sweeping changes to the global tax system in a century gained significant momentum on Thursday when 130 nations agreed to a blueprint in which multinational corporations would pay an appropriate share of tax wherever they operate.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman, Jim Tankersley and Eshe Nelson

articles.headline: Robinhood Reveals Rising Revenue and a $1.4 Billion Loss
articles.snippet: The stock-trading app unveiled its initial public offering prospectus on Thursday, pulling back the curtain on its financial performance for the first time.
articles.abstract: The stock-trading app unveiled its initial public offering prospectus on Thursday, pulling back the curtain on its financial performance for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Robinhood, the stock-trading app that grew in popularity and notoriety during the pandemic, revealed skyrocketing revenue and a loss of more than $1.4 billion in the first three months of this year, as it took a key step on Thursday toward one of the year’s most anticipated initial public offerings.

articles.headline: Budget Deficit Projected to Hit $3 Trillion as Pandemic Spending Buoys Economy
articles.snippet: Stimulus spending will help fuel economic growth and erase pandemic job losses, according to a new report from the Congressional Budget Office.
articles.abstract: Stimulus spending will help fuel economic growth and erase pandemic job losses, according to a new report from the Congressional Budget Office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy is rebounding from the pandemic downturn faster than expected and is on track to regain all the jobs lost during the coronavirus by the middle of next year, partly as a result of enormous amounts of federal spending that will push the budget deficit to $3 trillion for the 2021 fiscal year, the Congressional Budget Office said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Collapse Wasn’t First for Inspector Who Said Tower Seemed in ‘Good Shape’
articles.snippet: The chief building official of Surfside, Fla., had worked in at least six South Florida cities. The collapse of a 13-story condo tower prompted a review of his work in at least one city.
articles.abstract: The chief building official of Surfside, Fla., had worked in at least six South Florida cities. The collapse of a 13-story condo tower prompted a review of his work in at least one city.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — José L. Haar is still claustrophobic and suffers from chronic back pain, lingering effects from the hours he spent trapped under rubble between two dead brothers decades ago.

articles.headline: U.S. Leaves Its Last Afghan Base, Effectively Ending Operations
articles.snippet: With little fanfare, Bagram Air Base — once the military’s nerve center — was handed over to the Afghans, after nearly 20 years of waging war from the hub.
articles.abstract: With little fanfare, Bagram Air Base — once the military’s nerve center — was handed over to the Afghans, after nearly 20 years of waging war from the hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American troops and their Western allies have departed the U.S. military base that coordinated the sprawling war in Afghanistan, officials said on Friday, effectively ending major U.S. military operations in the country after nearly two decades.

articles.headline: Bezos’ Exit Is One of Many Among Amazon’s Top Ranks
articles.snippet: An unusual number of vice presidents are leaving for prominent jobs at public companies or high-growth start-ups.
articles.abstract: An unusual number of vice presidents are leaving for prominent jobs at public companies or high-growth start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Andy Jassy is elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, it will be one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.

articles.headline: Is Biden Declaring ‘Independence From the Virus’ Too Soon?
articles.snippet: Less than half the country is fully vaccinated against Covid-19, and the contagious Delta variant is spreading. Still, the White House has an “America’s Back Together” celebration planned for July 4.
articles.abstract: Less than half the country is fully vaccinated against Covid-19, and the contagious Delta variant is spreading. Still, the White House has an “America’s Back Together” celebration planned for July 4.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s plan to celebrate “independence from the virus” on the Fourth of July is running into an unpleasant reality: Less than half the country is fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, and the highly contagious Delta variant is threatening new outbreaks.

articles.headline: Halfway Through 2021, the Hot Stocks Are Old-Fashioned
articles.snippet: Pandemic-friendly tech companies touched off the market’s big rally last year. Now it’s being sustained by throwbacks like oil drillers and financial firms.
articles.abstract: Pandemic-friendly tech companies touched off the market’s big rally last year. Now it’s being sustained by throwbacks like oil drillers and financial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zoom and Peloton are out. Oil drillers and metal miners are in.

articles.headline: They Didn’t Expect to Retire Early. The Pandemic Changed Their Plans.
articles.snippet: After years in which Americans worked later in life, the latest economic disruption has driven many out of the work force prematurely.
articles.abstract: After years in which Americans worked later in life, the latest economic disruption has driven many out of the work force prematurely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dee Dee Patten, 57, hadn’t planned to retire early. But when the coronavirus-induced lockdown took hold in 2020 and business dried up at the mechanical repair shop that she and her husband, Dana, owned in Platteville, Colo., they decided to call it quits.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: U.S. Added 850,000 Jobs in June, and Wages Rose
articles.snippet: The resurgent economy delivered the strongest one-month employment gain since last summer, the latest promising signal about the recovery.
articles.abstract: The resurgent economy delivered the strongest one-month employment gain since last summer, the latest promising signal about the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anxieties over a lag in hiring lifted on Friday as the government reported that employers added 850,000 workers in June, the largest monthly gain since August.

articles.headline: A Pandemic Lifeline for Restaurants, Delivery Is ‘Here to Stay’
articles.snippet: As in-person dining returns, home delivery is holding up. For restaurants, services like DoorDash and Uber Eats could become a permanent part of their business.
articles.abstract: As in-person dining returns, home delivery is holding up. For restaurants, services like DoorDash and Uber Eats could become a permanent part of their business.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Last fall, as the weather cooled and coronavirus cases began to rise, May Seto, the owner of Grand Lake Kitchen in Oakland, refurbished a used pizza oven and started a takeout and delivery pizza business out of an extra kitchen where she had cooked for catering and private events.

articles.headline: As Afghan Forces Crumble, an Air of Unreality Grips the Capital
articles.snippet: With the Taliban advancing and U.S. troops leaving, President Ashraf Ghani and his aides have become increasingly insular, and Kabul is slipping into shock.
articles.abstract: With the Taliban advancing and U.S. troops leaving, President Ashraf Ghani and his aides have become increasingly insular, and Kabul is slipping into shock.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With his military crumbling, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan fired a crucial part of his command structure and brought in a new one. He created a nebulous “supreme state council,” announced months ago, that has hardly met. And as districts fall to the Taliban across the country, he has installed a giant picture of himself outside the airport’s domestic terminal.

articles.headline: At Sweetgreen, Seeing the Future of Work in a Desk Salad
articles.snippet: A favorite lunchtime destination of many urban office workers weathered the pandemic thanks to its digital savvy. It’s confident more people will be returning to their offices soon.
articles.abstract: A favorite lunchtime destination of many urban office workers weathered the pandemic thanks to its digital savvy. It’s confident more people will be returning to their offices soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: What can office desk salads tell us about the state of the pandemic?
